results.title: Day at the Show
results.creator_credit: State Film Centre of Victoria and Victoria. Audio-Visual Education Centre
results.brief_description: A visit to Melbourne’s Royal Show. Commentary designed for children showing the animals, pavilions, motor displays, show bags, fun fair and the grand parade ending with a fireworks display.

results.title: A Shame Like Alice. Part 2 (A)
results.creator_credit: Leonard Lee, SBS-TV and Lee Gordon Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “Focus”.
Presents the view of the white population of Alice Springs concerning its Aborigines, including those of the mayor and a councillor concerning “assimilation” problems. Shows, in contrast, Aboriginal self-help ventures in education and health. Aborigines relate their feelings about the intrusion of the media and tourism into their lives. Includes interviews with the then Senator Neville Bonner and former Commissioner for Community Affairs, Al Grassby.

results.title: A Shame like Alice. Part 1
results.creator_credit: Leonard Lee, SBS-TV and Lee Gordon Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Focus”.
A look at the plight of the Aboriginal people in and around Alice Springs, presenting the black viewpoint. Discusses racism in the town, the type of housing and services available to the Aboriginal people and other issues. Includes interviews with the then Senator Neville Bonner and former Commissioner for Community Relations, Al Grassby.

results.title: Get wet
results.creator_credit: Royal Life Saving Society and Image East
results.brief_description: The message of this humorous program featuring Jonathon Coleman is that water can be great fun providing you know how to enjoy it safely. Presents a number of typical scenarios - swimming pool, river and beach.

results.title: BabaKiueria
results.creator_credit: Geoffrey Atherden, Don Featherstone, Julian Pringle and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
‘BabaKiueria’ takes a satirical look at black-white relations in late twentieth century Australia, with a comic depiction of a racial role reversal. In documentary (or ‘mockumentary’) style, the film’s presenter investigates white lives in the fictitious land of ‘BabaKiueria’ (‘Barbeque Area’), where white people are a minority, living under black laws and suffering from discriminatory practices and attitudes held by the black majority. Written by Geoffrey Atherden (‘Mother and Son’, ‘Grass Roots’), the film was awarded a United Nations Media Peace Prize in 1987.
Stars Michelle Torres, Bob Maza, Kevin Smith, Cecily Polson, Tony Barry.

results.title: A Changing culture
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Rainbow serpent”.
David Gulpilil has become a success in the white man’s world, through his acting ability and leadership of a dance troupe. Yet he prefers to live in a traditional manner with his people in Arnhem Land, making brief forays into western society in order to publicise their plight and demonstrate the richness of their culture. Charmaine Green is a linguist student at the Australian National University. When she visits her family in Mullewa, W.A. and observes the hopeless life they lead on the fringes of western society, she feels that she cannot return there permanently, although she is determined not to deny her Aboriginality in spite of her light skin.

results.title: Twentieth Century Masters
results.creator_credit: Australian National Gallery, Peter Isaac and Terence Meast
results.brief_description: The Twentieth Century Masters video features a selection from the 71 works exhibited in the Twentieth Century Masters exhibition at the Australian National Gallery, Canberra and the Queensland Art Gallery, in 1986. Shot at the Australian National Gallery this video includes a number of works in the gallery’s permanent collection by artists represented in the exhibition. School of Paris artists discussed on the video tape include: Picasso, Matisse, Bonnard, Derain, Chagall, Soutine and Modigliani. Other European artists considered are Paul Klee and Max Beckmann.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Australian National Gallery, Peter Isaac and Terence Meast

results.title: Soldier settlers
results.brief_description: Portrays the progress made since 1945 in the establishment of ex-servicemen from World War II on Victorian land. The division of large estates, the development of existing pastures, the clearing of scrub country and the construction of irrigation channels are seen on representative farms throughout the state. Fruit growing, the dried fruit industry, wheat cultivation and sheep raising, plus dry and irrigated dairying are shown, in addition to the single-unit farm system.

results.title: Roland Robinson
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Writers Talking”.
A poet with a strong attachment to the Australian landscape, Roland Robinson has a deep interest in Aboriginal lore, and performs his poetry with a memorable verve.
